Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Real-Time Decision Making Software for Wastewater Treatment Operators
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is the development of a real-time software for wastewater facilities to improve nutrient removal and recovery at reduced costs. The technology developed through this SBIR project will provide a proactive monitoring process that allows wastewater operators to observe and diagnose future process upsets, proactively mitigate underlying root causes, and prevent pollutant release without the use of expensive and environmentally damaging chemicals. Improvements in treatment effectiveness and reduction of operating and maintenance costs will limit the environmental impact of human activities, improve sustainability of wastewater treatment infrastructure, ensure public health, and reduce financial burdens associated with wastewater treatment. Following deployment individual facilities may see annual commercial savings upwards of $1.4 M per large facility from improved compliance and reduction in chemical costs in a wastewater services, a market opportunity estimated at upwards of $420 M in the United States. This project could lead to 35% improvement in regulatory compliance, 35% reduction in chemical treatment costs, and a guidance system for inexperienced operators in an industry expecting 50% of its operator workforce to retire over the next 5-10 years. In addition, the project will develop a game-based training program to train new operators in the skill sets to lead operation of sophisticated facilities. <br/><br/>This SBIR Phase II project proposes to further the development of a software platform that uses available operational, biological, and meteorological data as inputs to deliver process forecasts and insights regarding biological phosphorus removal to operators. Machine-learning forecast models will be the basis of an attribution-based inference and decision-making system used for diagnosis and mitigation of upsets to the notoriously unstable biological phosphorus removal process. In this project, data systems of a full-scale wastewater facility will be synced with the software platform to deliver real-time results that will be evaluated over 12 months of pilot testing.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) funded project, "Real-Time Decision-Making Software for Wastewater Treatment Operators," has successfully reached its conclusion following a collaborative period of research, development, and implementation. The project's primary objective was the development of an Artificial Intelligence (AI) software designed to optimize wastewater treatment processes, thereby addressing the critical challenges faced by the sector.

We made significant strides in the field of wastewater treatment and AI. The cornerstone of the project was a novel hybrid mechanistic-machine learning model. This model successfully forecasted conditions, executed multiple simulations, and optimized chemical dosing at the pilot site, demonstrating the transformative potential of AI in this vital sector. Additionally, we developed a simulator-based game to enhance operator knowledge and digital literacy. This innovative approach is aimed at addressing the projected workforce deficit in the sector, thereby ensuring the sustainability of these essential services.

The broader impacts of our work are substantial and far-reaching. The AI software we developed enables wastewater treatment operators to make informed, real-time decisions, leading to cost savings and improved treatment outcomes. During the pilot phase, we projected potential annual cost savings from chemical use reduction for a 15-25 MGD facility to be $200,000 to $350,000. This significant reduction underscores the economic benefits of our project.

In conclusion, the project not only met its set milestones and objectives but also made a significant contribution to the wastewater treatment sector. We are grateful to the NSF for their support and eagerly anticipate the broader implementation and impact of this project.

This project stands as a testament to the power of AI in addressing critical societal challenges. The outcomes of this project will have a lasting impact, not only in the field of wastewater treatment but also in how we approach and solve complex issues related to water quality, environmental justice, and sustainability.

 


Last Modified: 07/29/2023
Modified by: Keaton L Lesnik
